clinical_study.brief_title: Skeletal Muscle and Platelet Mitochondrial Dysfunction During Sepsis
clinical_study.official_title: Skeletal Muscle and Platelet Mitochondrial Dysfunction During Sepsis

lead_sponsor.agency: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

collaborator.agency: European Society of Intensive Care Medicine

clinical_study.source: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

brief_summary.textblock: The primary aim of the study is to demonstrate that mitochondrial dysfunction occurs in both skeletal muscle and circulating platelets of severely septic and septic shock ICU-admitted patients. Secondary aims are to clarify the pathogenesis and the clinical relevance of mitochondrial damage during sepsis.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary aim of the study is to demonstrate that mitochondrial dysfunction occurs in both skeletal muscle and circulating platelets of severely septic and septic shock ICU-admitted patients, as compared to otherwise healthy surgical ones. In order to better clarify the pathogenesis of mitochondrial dysfunction during sepsis, cardiogenic shock patients (suffering from systemic hypoperfusion) will act as additional controls. Markers of oxidative stress will be measured in tissue samples from septic patients. The clinical relevance of mitochondrial dysfunction during sepsis will be assessed in terms of both skeletal muscle and platelet function.

primary_outcome.time_frame: On day one and seven from admission to ICU

study_pop.textblock: Adult ICU-admitted severely septic and septic shock patientes; adult ICU-admitted cardiogenic shock patients; surgical patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Consecutive ICU-admitted severely septic or septic shock patients.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe thrombocytopenia.
- Severe coagulopathy.
- Pre-existing mitochondrial disease
